awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Implications of Diverse Environmental Knowledge for Community Conservation
awd_abstract_narration:
Indigenous and local environmental knowledge plays a vital role in community-based conservation in the United States and across the world. Deploying such knowledge to inform community decision making regarding natural resource management, however, involves complex negotiations between stakeholders, who often have differing environmental perspectives. By investigating how diverse knowledge shapes the dynamics of collective governance of community conserved areas, this doctoral dissertation research sheds light on some of the more challenging aspects of community conservation policy and practice, such as knowledge integration and stakeholder equity. The dissemination of research results to policy makers and academic and general audiences will raise awareness of the value of Indigenous and local knowledge for biodiversity conservation while emphasizing its diversity and complexity. This project trains a graduate student in anthropology in the methods of scientific data collection and analysis and exemplifies the importance of scientifically investigating the epistemological aspects of community-based natural resource management in order to foster more successful conservation outcomes.

This project analyzes how different types of knowledge come into contact to influence conservation processes and the effects of these varied epistemologies on the governance and representation of an Indigenous community conserved area. Specifically, the researchers examine how knowledge holders mobilize environmental ideas, beliefs, and values to validate opinions about natural resource management and how differing perspectives are contested or adopted in order to achieve consensus-based collective action. Qualitative methods and a multi-scalar and multi-sited research design are utilized to assess the role of knowledge in shaping conservation processes at an individual, community, and organization level. Determining the types of knowledge Indigenous communities mobilize to manage and conserve biodiversity enhances our theoretical understanding of Indigenous and local environmental knowledge. Additionally, ascertaining the role of such knowledges in the negotiation of conservation problems helps expand scientific comprehension of the interpersonal and epistemological processes inherent to collective action and environmental governance.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The central goal of the project is to assess the implications of diverse environmental knowledge for indigenous conservation governance and representation. This assessment was carried out through field work with the indigenous Kichwa people of Sarayaku at multiple sites across Pastaza Province, in the central Amazonian region of Ecuador.

 

In recent decades, the International Union for Conservation of Nature has recognized that indigenous and local communities successfully manage and govern protected areas, many autonomously, through the use of local environmental knowledge. However, local knowledge has been shown to be socially variable, changing, and hybrid, implying that communities must negotiate diverse environmental perspectives in order to collectively govern and represent their protected areas. Applying theoretical insights of scholarship on indigenous and local knowledge (ILK) to the realm of community conservation, this research traces how diverse knowledge claims are negotiated in decision making processes at different scales of conservation governance and representation, using a multi-level and multi-sited case study of an Ecuadorian indigenous community conserved area (ICCA). Ethnographic research will be carried out to determine the types of knowledge used to shape conservation processes at the individual, community, and organization level during thirteen months of fieldwork in Pastaza Province. The proposed research offers an analysis of the intra-cultural negotiation of knowledge claims from the community to the organizational level, to determine how different types of knowledge (e.g. traditional, spiritual, technical, ecological) come into contact to influence conservation processes and the effects of these varied epistemologies on the governance and representation of an ICCA.

 

More specifically, there are three major goals of the project:

 

1. To evaluate what types of knowledge shape local understandings of the environment and how they are articulated differently by diverse individuals in and across communities.

2. To assess what types of knowledge guide internal governance of an Indigenous Community Conserved Area and how they are collectively negotiated by community representatives.

3. To assess what types of knowledge inform external representation of an Indigenous Community Conserved Area and how they are collectively negotiated by organization leaders and staff members.

 

During the 6 months of research supported by the NSF DDRIG, I completed the following data collection activities. I spent the six months of Phase 1 conducting participant observation and semistructured interviews in Pastaza Province in order to collect data on individual conceptualizations of rainforest cosmology and conservation. Data was collected on local notions of the rainforest ecosystem, cultural institutions which dictate human interaction with nature, and traditional livelihood practices. I conducted over 30 semistructured interviews with adult community members who were representatives and administrators of the ICCA or political leaders and activists; community members who regularly attend ICCA meetings; and elder community members, shamans, or cultural specialists who are considered holders of traditional knowledge. My time was divided between primary sites of governance and administration of the ICCA initiative in Puyo, and the site of the actual ICCA in the community of Sarayaku. During the six months of Phase 1, I visited the community of Sarayaku three times, often staying up to a week each visit. During these visits I was able to conduct interviews, observe events, and take tours of the ICCA rainforest. Overall, I consider the research results to be satisfactory, and I have now begun carrying out Phase 2 of the project. 


My dissertation research will produce a case study of an ICCA, an understudied and underrecognized protected area model that supports both indigenous cultural survival and the conservation of nature. As such, education and outreach is an important component of my project outcomes. My planned activities are designed to reach three target audiences: policy makers, academics, and the general public. Firstly, a collaborative article, written with one of the leaders of Sarayaku, on the history, successes, and challenges of The Living Forest ICCA, will be prepared for inclusion in a interdisciplinary anthology on conservation and social justice which is aimed at conservation policy makers and practitioners. In addition, my dissertation will be written in the form of three scholarly articles, one of which will be submitted to a journal of conservation policy, such as Conservation Letters or Environment and Society. Secondly, results will be disseminated to academic audiences through presentations at the University San Francisco of Quito in Ecuador, at North American academic conferences, and through publication in various anthropological journals which will enable the results to reach both U.S. and global academic circles. Thirdly, the publication of a magazine article, participation in locally organized Ted Talks, and the creation of a multi-media blog and use of other digital communication tools will help communicate the results beyond academic circles to general audiences.
